item.title: 'Providers are protected': New Mexico bill defends abortion rights
item.description: New Mexico has taken steps to strengthen abortion access after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling overturned a woman’s decision to end a pregnancy as a constitutional right. Legislators advanced a bill defending providers from out-of-state interference.
item.dc:creator: Morgan Lee

item.title: In aftermath of Tyre Nichols, Memphis seeks to rewrite its story
item.description: Tyre Nichols’ death seemed to cement Memphis’ reputation for crime and poverty. But residents look at their city and see promise, too.
item.dc:creator: Noah Robertson

item.title: How these HBCU presidents fixed their colleges’ financial futures
item.description: Historically Black Colleges and Universities have grappled with a long history of being ignored financially. What’s different today, several presidents say, is that people outside of HBCU circles are starting to notice the inequities.
item.dc:creator: Ira Porter

item.title: Internet speech: Supreme Court to weigh who is protected online
item.description: Two cases before the U.S. Supreme Court this week challenge Section 230, a 1996 law that protects tech companies from liability for material posted on their networks. The cases are part of a global trend toward holding social media platforms accountable.
item.dc:creator: Barbara Orotutay

item.title: Biden to border asylum seekers: Ask other countries first
item.description: The Biden administration will now generally deny migrants who have not already sought asylum in a country they passed through prior to reaching the U.S. border. A similar move by the Trump administration was blocked in court.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Santana and Elliot Spagat

item.title: Profile in courage: When Jimmy Carter saved a nuclear reactor
item.description: With the former president having entered hospice, a little-known chapter from Jimmy Carter’s naval career illustrates his courage and problem-solving skills under hazardous conditions.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier
Kieran Murphy

item.title: Michael Cox was beaten by Boston police. Now he leads them.
item.description: Boston Police Commissioner Michael Cox doesn’t want to be defined by a past injustice, but by his insistence on constitutional policing today.
item.dc:creator: Kalpana Jain

item.title: ‘You have to find the small lights’: The challenges for quake-hit Turkey
item.description: The World Bank’s Alanna Simpson, who has worked on seismic risks in Turkey, speaks with the Monitor about the lessons of past quakes and the country’s response to the recent devastating temblor.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Hills

item.title: In politics, there are no second acts. Enter Kari Lake.
item.description: One of the clearest messages to emerge from the 2022 elections was voters’ rejection of politicians who echoed former President Donald Trump’s claims of electoral fraud. Where does that leave Kari Lake?
item.dc:creator: Simon Montlake

item.title: Taking on Trump: How 2024 might be different from 2016
item.description: A crowded GOP presidential field could help Donald Trump win the nomination again. But many factors are different – including Mr. Trump’s unique status as a “pseudo-incumbent.”
item.dc:creator: Linda Feldmann

item.title: Balloons and national security: What we know so far
item.description: Here’s what we are learning about just how many foreign objects, and what type, may be routinely coming into our airspace. Is this mostly an annoyance or a real national security problem?
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier
Christa Case Bryant

item.title: Families are leaving public schools. How will that change education?
item.description: The pandemic led to enrollment declines in public schools across the United States. As more parents mull other options, how are districts rethinking their bottom line – and their mission?
item.dc:creator: Jackie Valley

item.title: Half of Americans might not trust this article, new poll finds
item.description: A new Gallup poll finds that 50% of Americans believe national news media intentionally misinform their audience and “do not care about the best interests of readers.” The survey also found 88% of people between the ages of 18 to 25 get their news online.
item.dc:creator: David Bauder

item.title: Why one Arkansas town has pinned its hopes on a teen mayor
item.description: Generation Z is stepping up in national politics and state legislature – and in this small Arkansas town. Instead of heading away to college, 18-year-old Jaylen Smith ran for mayor, and won.
item.dc:creator: Sophie Hills

item.title: Michigan State University reels, seeks answers to gunman's motive
item.description: A shooter opened fire on students at Michigan State University Monday night, killing three and wounding five. The shooting is the latest in a spate of deadly shootings this year in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Joey Cappelletti and Ken Kusmer

item.title: Nikki Haley, former Trump cabinet member, enters GOP presidential race
item.description: Nikki Haley announced her presidential campaign on Tuesday through a tweeted video. She is the first major Republican challenger to Donald Trump for the 2024 race. If elected, she would become the first woman and person of Indian descent in the Oval Office.
item.dc:creator: Meg Kinnard

item.title: ‘You can’t heal what you don’t reveal’: Archives as a path to justice
item.description: How does history affect the future? The Riverside Church in New York is turning to its archival collections not only for an honest assessment of its past but also for guidance on its next steps.
item.dc:creator: Maisie Sparks

item.title: Who goes to jail over classified docs – and who doesn’t?
item.description: Some experts say higher-level officials are less likely to be prosecuted for mishandling secret information. Others argue it all depends on the details of the case.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grier
Noah Robertson

item.title: Republican campaigns increasingly aim to shape school curriculums
item.description: More conservative politicians are raising concerns about education and promoting a “parents’ rights” movement leading up to the 2024 presidential race. It could be an effort to win over suburban women who have left the GOP, says one political analyst.
item.dc:creator: Michelle L. Price

item.title: From UFOs to balloons, US on ‘heightened alert’ with air space safety
item.description: The U.S. is now on the lookout for slower flying objects after shooting down a Chinese balloon, said the head of NORAD and U.S. Northern Command Gen. Glen VanHerck. In recent days fighter jets have targeted objects over Canada, Alaska, and Lake Huron.
item.dc:creator: Colleen Long, Lolita C. Baldor, and Zeke Miller
